messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 66 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Reconstruction Algorithms for Low-Rank Tensors and Depth-3 Multilinear Circuits.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We give new and efficient black-box reconstruction algorithms for some classes of depth-333 arithmetic circuits. As a consequence, we obtain the first efficient algorithm for computing the tensor rank and for finding the optimal tensor decomposition as a sum of rank-one tensors when then input is a constant-rank tensor. More specifically, we provide efficient learning algorithms that run in randomized polynomial time over general fields and in deterministic polynomial time over ‚Ñù‚Ñù{\mathbb{R}} and ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ{\mathbb{C}} for the following classes: 1. Set-multilinear depth-333 circuits of constant top fan-in (Œ£‚ÄãŒ†‚ÄãŒ£{‚äîjXj}‚Äã(k)Œ£Œ†subscriptŒ£subscriptsquare-unionùëósubscriptùëãùëóùëò\Sigma\Pi\Sigma_{{\left\{\sqcup_{j}X_{j}\right\}}}(k) circuits). As a consequence of our algorithm, we obtain the first polynomial time algorithm for tensor rank computation and optimal tensor decomposition of constant-rank tensors. This result holds for dùëëd dimensional tensors for any dùëëd, but is interesting even for d=3ùëë3d=3. 2. Sums of powers of constantly many linear forms (Œ£‚àßŒ£‚Äã(k)Œ£Œ£ùëò\Sigma\!\wedge\!\Sigma(k) circuits). As a consequence we obtain the first polynomial-time algorithm for tensor rank computation and optimal tensor decomposition of constant-rank symmetric tensors. 3. Multilinear depth-3 circuits of constant top fan-in (multilinear Œ£‚ÄãŒ†‚ÄãŒ£‚Äã(k)Œ£Œ†Œ£ùëò\Sigma\Pi\Sigma(k) circuits). Our algorithm works over all fields of characteristic 0 or large enough characteristic. Prior to our work the only efficient algorithms known were over polynomially-sized finite fields [KS09a]. Prior to our work, the only polynomial-time or even subexponential-time algorithms known (deterministic or randomized) for subclasses of Œ£‚ÄãŒ†‚ÄãŒ£‚Äã(k)Œ£Œ†Œ£ùëò\Sigma\Pi\Sigma(k) circuits that also work over large/infinite fields were for the setting when the top fan-in kùëòk is at most 222 [Sin16, Sin20].

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 66 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 66"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Proving lower bounds via pseudo-random generators",
        "Unbalancing sets and an almost quadratic lower bound for syntactically multilinear arithmetic circuits",
        "Open problems in number theoretic complexity, II",
        "The monomial ideal membership problem and polynomial identity testing",
        "Queries and concept learning",
        "Arithmetic circuits: A chasm at depth four",
        "Derandomizing polynomial identity testing for multilinear constant-read formulae",
        "Learning functions represented as multiplicity automata",
        "A deterministic algorithm for sparse multivariate polynominal interpolation",
        "Reconstruction of depth-4 multilinear circuits",
        "Some algebraic and geometric computations in pspace",
        "Reducing the number of variables of a polynomial",
        "Learning algorithms from natural proofs",
        "Ideals, varieties, and algorithms - an introduction to computational algebraic geometry and commutative algebra (4. ed.)",
        "Learning polynomials in few relevant dimensions",
        "A probabilistic remark on algebraic program testing",
        "Locally decodable codes with 2 queries and polynomial identity testing for depth 3 circuits",
        "Efficient learning algorithms yield circuit lower bounds",
        "Quasipolynomial-time identity testing of non-commutative and read-once oblivious algebraic branching programs",
        "Hitting sets for multilinear read-once algebraic branching programs, in any order",
        "Arithmetic circuits: A chasm at depth three",
        "Efficient reconstruction of random multilinear formulas",
        "Reconstruction of depth-4 multilinear circuits with top fanin 2",
        "Random arithmetic formulas can be reconstructed efficiently",
        "Learning sums of powers of low-degree polynomials in the non-degenerate case",
        "Solving systems of polynomial inequalities in subexponential time",
        "Tensor rank is np-complete",
        "Solvability of systems of polynomial congruences modulo a large prime",
        "Quantifier elimination in the theory of an algebraically-closed field",
        "An Introduction to Differential Algebra",
        "Efficient algorithms for some special cases of the polynomial equivalence problem",
        "Derandomizing polynomial identity tests means proving circuit lower bounds",
        "Average-case linear matrix factorization and reconstruction of low width algebraic branching programs",
        "Reconstruction of full rank algebraic branching programs",
        "Hilbert‚Äôs nullstellensatz is in the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Arithmetic circuits: the chasm at depth four gets wider",
        "Randomness efficient identity testing of multivariate polynomials",
        "Learning restricted models of arithmetic circuits",
        "Polynomial identity testing for depth 3 circuits",
        "Deterministic black box polynomial identity testing of depth-3 arithmetic circuits with bounded top fan-in",
        "Reconstruction of generalized depth-3 arithmetic circuits with bounded top fan-in",
        "Blackbox polynomial identity testing for depth 3 circuits",
        "Cryptographic hardness for learning intersections of halfspaces",
        "Black box polynomial identity testing of generalized depth-3 arithmetic circuits with bounded top fan-in",
        "Reconstruction of non-degenerate homogeneous depth three circuits",
        "Computing with polynomials given by black boxes for their evaluations: Greatest common divisors, factorization, separation of numerators and denominators",
        "Tensors: geometry and applications",
        "Reduction of an arbitrary diophantine equation to one in 13 unknowns",
        "Tensor-rank and lower bounds for arithmetic formulas",
        "Fast probabilistic algorithms for verification of polynomial identities",
        "How hard is the tensor rank?",
        "Interpolation of depth-3 arithmetic circuits with two multiplication gates",
        "Reconstruction of real depth-3 circuits with top fan-in 2",
        "Efficient reconstruction of depth three circuits with top fan-in two",
        "An almost optimal rank bound for depth-3 identities",
        "From Sylvester-Gallai Configurations to Rank Bounds: Improved Black-Box Identity Test for Deph-3 Circuits",
        "Blackbox identity testing for bounded top-fanin depth-3 circuits: The field doesn‚Äôt matter",
        "From sylvester-gallai configurations to rank bounds: Improved blackbox identity test for depth-3 circuits",
        "The complexity of tensor rank",
        "Algebra and computation",
        "On the relation between polynomial identity testing and finding variable disjoint factors",
        "Read-once polynomial identity testing",
        "Blackbox identity testing for depth-4 multilinear circuits",
        "Arithmetic circuits: A survey of recent results and open questions",
        "Improved bounds for reduction to depth 4 and depth 3",
        "Probabilistic algorithms for sparse polynomials"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 66 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Reconstruction Algorithms for Low-Rank Tensors and Depth-3 Multilinear Circuits., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
